reﬂect the IRS requirement that IR manuals address Controls (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls memo dated September

Internal Controls are the program manuals policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, and officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the: a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms are deﬁned; and b. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. (
) To conform to the new Internal Controls standards: a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates program manual’s mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agents assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
is added to provide the legal authorities for the program manual
, Processing Completed Criminal Investigation Reports. c. New subsection
is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used the program manual
, Processing Completed Criminal Investigation Reports. (

9.5.12.1 through 9.5.12.1.2 reﬂect the IRS requirement that IR manuals address (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and of Internal Controls memo dated September 14, 2016. Internal Controls are the manuals policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, and charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the:
Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms are deﬁned; and Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations.
a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agents assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
is added to provide the legal authorities for the program manual
, Processing Completed Criminal Investigation Reports. c. New subsection
is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual
, Processing Completed Criminal Investigation Reports.

Subsection 9.5.12.2.1 paragraph (9) is revised to emphasize that the Supervisory Special Agent (SSA) has the “option” to complete Form 6082 - Assessment of Closed General/Subject Seizure/Primary/Subject Investigation Narrative Appraisal.
Additional revisions, deletions, grammatical changes were made throughout the section which did not result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 9.5.12, dated 04-21-2008. This IRM also incorporates procedures implemented by the IRS Deputy Commissioners memorandum dated September 14, 2016, [Subject: Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls].

ommendation report review process. The guidelines and procedures for Criminal Investigation special agents and managers to follow in processing prosecution recommendations. The referral authority for prosecution recommendation to the Depart

The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

Acronym Deﬁnition ASAC Assistant Special Agent in Charge CCR Centralized Case Review CEM Criminal Evaluation Memorandum CPA Certiﬁed Public Accountant CT Criminal Tax DOJ Department of Justice OCDETF Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force SAC Special Agent in Charge SAR Special Agent Report SCIP Simultaneous Criminal Investigation Program SEP Special Enforcement Program SOI Summary of Investigation SSA Supervisory Special Agent
The following subsections cover the respective responsibilities of those involved in the prosecution recommendation report review process.

) The SSA has the following responsibilities prior to forwarding the recommendation report to CCR: of the a. Read the prosecution recommendation report for general quality, com- pleteness, and sufficiency of evidence. b. Ensure the proper method of proof is utilized. c. Ensure computer generated schedules and appendices include an tronic version (read only ﬁle) of the schedules/appendices for purposes (on disk or by e-mail). d. Ensure non-computer generated appendices with mathematical tions are accurate. e. Initiate a CI Report Control Log, Form

) a-e, are completed, the SSA will: a. Forward the ﬁnalized prosecution recommendation report package includes the SAR, List of Witnesses and Exhibits, Appendices, Summary of Witness Testimony and Records Document and Control to CCR. Note: Special Agents in Charge have the option of referring non-tax prosecution recommendations without sending them to CCR and CT Counsel for review. All tax and tax-related tion recommendations and all sensitive non-tax prosecution recommendations must be reviewed by CT Counsel. b. Include any advice provided during the investigation by CT Counsel. c. Communicate to CCR in advance of submission if there is a year(s) with an early statute of limitations. d. Note on the control log the request for priority review of the recommendation report relative to investigations with an early statute limitations. (

) If exhibits are voluminous, the option of an on-site review should be consid- ered. In special situations where arrangements are made in advance, it not be possible to provide all of the exhibits. In those instances, the whether to review exhibits will be made by CCR. (
) Upon receipt of the SAR and Control Log (Form

) from the CCR, the will review the CCR’s comments and recommendation. At the discretion of SSA, they may forward the SAR directly to CT Counsel; or they may have assigned special agent address some or all of the CCR’s recommendations prior to sending it to CT Counsel. If the CCR calls for signiﬁcant/major to the SAR, it will need to be sent back through the CCR after changes are made and prior to submission to CT Counsel. (

Criminal Investigation Reports
page c. Communicate to CT Counsel in advance of submission if there is a ecution year(s) with an early statute of limitations. (

) During CT Counsel’s review, once all substantive issues are resolved, the will request technical assistance to review the tax computations through the appropriate operating division Territory Manager. Technical assistance will be based on available resources of appropriate operating division. If a agent is assigned to the investigation, the cooperating agent will be assigned to compute the criminal tax for CT Counsel. A SEP agent will be assigned in other instances unless there are no available SEP agents or the area has no SEP resources. If a SEP agent is not available, then a general program will be assigned to assist CT Counsel. The SSA will prepare a memorandum from the SAC to the operating division Territory Manager requesting the as- signment of a cooperating/SEP/general program agent to review the tax computations. (

) When the prosecution recommendation report is returned by CT Counsel, SSA will: a. Ensure that the assigned special agent addresses CT Counsel’s mendations. b. Ensure that the special agent prepares a ﬁnalized prosecution recom- mendation report for approval. (

) When the prosecution recommendation report is ﬁnalized, the SSA will: a. Review the prosecution recommendation report for quality and ness. b. Ensure all CCR and CT Counsel recommendations are addressed. ommendations that are not accepted will be discussed in the control c. Update the control log. d. Sign the prosecution recommendation report and forward the report to the SAC, through the ASAC as appropriate, along with the list of witnesses and exhibits, appendices, exhibits, summary of witness testimony and records, CT Counsel recommendations, and control log. (

) The SSA has the option to complete the Assessment of Closed General/ Subject Seizure/Primary/Subject Investigation Narrative Appraisal, Form at the conclusion of the investigation whether the investigation is declined, or adjudicated. (

) The Centralized Case Review will review all sensitive, tax and tax-related ecution recommendation reports, including grand jury recommendations. At discretion of the SAC, the CCR will review non-sensitive, non-tax recommendation reports. The CCR and CT Counsel are required to review sensitive investigations, deﬁned per IRM

, General, Primary, and Investigations. Note: The SAC may make exceptions to the general policy relating to the CCR’s review of prosecution reports in unusual situations. These exceptions will documented in the investigative ﬁle with a memorandum signed by the explaining the circumstances relating to the exception. The SAC will a copy of the exception memorandum to the CCR assigned to the ﬁeld office. The memorandum will also accompany the SAR package to the CT Attorney.

The Centralized Case Review will review all sensitive, tax and tax-related pros- ecution recommendation reports, including grand jury recommendations. At the discretion of the SAC, the CCR will review non-sensitive, non-tax prosecution recommendation reports. The CCR and CT Counsel are required to review all sensitive investigations, deﬁned per IRM
, General, Primary, and Subject

The SAC may make exceptions to the general policy relating to the CCR’s review of prosecution reports in unusual situations. These exceptions will be documented in the investigative ﬁle with a memorandum signed by the SAC explaining the circumstances relating to the exception. The SAC will provide a copy of the exception memorandum to the CCR assigned to the ﬁeld office. The memorandum will also accompany the SAR package to the CT Attorney.
h. ensure the use of correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation i. recommend to the SSA any report revisions or additional investigative actions (

) At the conclusion of their review, the CCR will: a. Make a determination in the control log as to the sufficient quality, pleteness, and organization of the prosecution recommendation package before it is forwarded to CT Counsel for review of legal suffi- ciency. b. Forward tax and tax-related prosecution recommendation reports to submitting SSA. Note: If the prosecution recommendation report is returned to the SSA for cant re-work, the CCR should follow-up with the SSA to ensure the prosecution recommendation report is resubmitted to CCR. c. Forward a copy of the control log with the recommendation and error code listings to the SSA and/or CT Counsel. (
) The CCR will maintain ﬁles and records on all reviews to permit tracking of investigations, trends, and evaluation of the quality of their work in with record retention procedures. (
) The CCR will keep the Directors, Field Operations and the SACs timely informed of trends and needed changes or modiﬁcations in plans, procedures and programs. (

) Investigations with an early statute of limitations are priority review and be noted on the control log by the SSA. Request for an expedite review considered on a case by case basis with conﬂicts resolved by the Director, Field Operations or his/her designee. All other investigations will be in the order received. (
) All time spent by the CCR to review a prosecution recommendation report be charged as direct investigative time to that particular investigation. (

) Criminal Tax Counsel will review sensitive, tax and tax-related prosecution ommendation reports for legal sufficiency. At the request of the SAC, CT Counsel will review non-sensitive, non-tax prosecution recommendation reports.
All time spent by the CCR to review a prosecution recommendation report will be charged as direct investigative time to that particular investigation.

) The following subsections provide guidelines and procedures for CI to follow processing prosecution recommendations. (
) A taxpayer conference will be offered as a matter of course. A taxpayer who the subject of a criminal prosecution recommendation will be afforded a Conference ence with the SAC and CT Counsel. (

) The taxpayer conference will not be held if the taxpayer is the subject of a grand jury investigation or if the SAC determines that such a conference not be in the best interest of the government. (
) If a taxpayer conference is held, it should be done before the SAC makes a referral to the DOJ, Tax Division. (
) The SAC determines the location of the taxpayer conference. (
) The SAC may designate an ASAC to conduct the taxpayer conference with Conference Counsel. and (

) At the option of the SAC, CT Counsel may prepare the letter for the SAC’s signature to the taxpayer and/or representative offering a conference at a the Taxpayer location designated by the SAC or his/her designee.
Ensure conclusions and recommendations are factually consistent with the evidence presented. Ensure CCR’s concerns and recommendations are appropriately addressed. Conduct an in
depth review only to resolve variances from CCR and CT Counsel’s recommendations. Send referral memo to DOJ, Tax Division identify any unresolved differ

ences with CT Counsel. Ensure copies of the completed control log, transmittals, and prosecution recommendation report are forwarded to the SSA, CCR, and CT Ensure a copy of the CEM (and criminal tax computation attachment) is forwarded to CCR.

) At the conference, the SAC or his/her designee will give a general oral statement of the alleged violations and the facts supporting the investigation the extent possible while still protecting the government’s interests. facts and ﬁgures will be made available to the taxpayer to acquaint him/her with the basis, nature, and other essential elements of the proposed criminal charges (see
CFR

)). Extreme care must be exercised to ensure that no information is disclosed to the taxpayer which might: a. reveal or indicate the identity of conﬁdential informants b. endanger prospective witnesses c. prove detrimental to the prosecution of the investigation (
) At the beginning of the taxpayer conference, the taxpayer will be read constitutional rights against self-incrimination. (

) The taxpayer may be accompanied at the conference by an attorney, CPA, enrolled agent, or any individual who has knowledge of the facts or who can give information which will assist in establishing the facts in the However, the SAC or his/her designee may terminate the conference or bar any person(s) accompanying the taxpayer from attendance if their presence deemed disruptive. While a third party’s presence is considered implied consent for disclosure when accompanying the taxpayer, (see IRM

, closure of Official Information), a written authorization from the taxpayer, consenting to or requesting such disclosure, will be required. This may be oral in those instances where the taxpayer’s statement is being recorded. (

) When a taxpayer’s representative, who has furnished a power of attorney or tax information authorization, attends the conference without the taxpayer, representative is entitled to receive (to the extent authorized by the the same information that would be furnished if the taxpayer were present. (
) At the conclusion of the taxpayer conference, CT Counsel will prepare a ference memorandum. The memorandum is reviewed and signed by the and CT Counsel.

) The SAC will send a letter to the taxpayer advising of the decision on the pros- ecution recommendation. (

) After the formal conference, the special agent and CT Counsel will discuss the defenses raised by the taxpayer and/or the taxpayer’s representative and determine if those defenses warrant further inquiries. (

) When DOJ, Tax Division concurs with a prosecution recommendation, prosecu- tion is authorized and the prosecution recommendation is forwarded to the appropriate US Attorney’s Office or assigned to a DOJ, Tax Division attorney. (
) If DOJ, Tax Division or the US Attorney declines to prosecute a referral, the investigation is returned to the SAC of the referring ﬁeld office.
